thread.title: How many empty seats will we see at Saturday night's Oregon-Colorado game? Issues & Answers
thread.title_full: How many empty seats will we see at Saturday night's Oregon-Colorado game? Issues & Answers | OregonLive.com

author: Ken Goe | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: How many empty seats will we see at Saturday night's Oregon-Colorado game? Issues & Answers
text:
The Pac-12 television package was sold as a way to increase the conference's national visibility while also padding the member schools' bottom line. In practice, it hasn't turned out so well.
While television revenue has increased, the Pac-12 is being left behind by the Big Ten and SEC.
And, conference games are being wedged into late night time slots that often are inconvenient for local fans.
There are four Pac-12 games on Saturday. Two start at 10 p.m. or later on the East Coast. How does this enhance the conference's national visibility?
The Oregon-Colorado game kicks at 8 p.m. MDT on what is forecast to be a cool, wet Saturday night. It's not going to do much for CU's home attendance, which already hasn't been good.
But, hey, it will fill ESPN's need for late Saturday programming.
The Stanford-Arizona game kicks at 7:30 p.m. on the Pac-12 Networks. That doesn't bode well for the attendance in Stanford Stadium either, and it splits what already should be a minuscule live viewing audience in the Eastern Time Zone.
Oregon fans can take solace in the knowledge that their game isn't the one being shunted onto the Pac-12 Nets. At least DirecTV watchers can see it.
OK, more links:
Hayden Kim of the Oregon Daily Emerald: History should show Oregon coach Mark Helfrich that business as usual isn't necessarily the best response to troubled times.
Does Oregon have the strong internal leadership necessary to rally from the Utah debacle and win at Colorado; it's one thing I'll be watching this week. (Video).
The Merc's Jon Wilner picks Colorado and Arizona State (plus the points), although he has Oregon and UCLA winning the games.
Oregon has whiffed on recruiting quarterbacks since landing Marcus Mariota.
UO coach Mark Helfrich remains opaque about injuries to receiver Byron Marshall and corner Chris Seisay.
Reports that Seisay has had foot surgery is the worst possible news for a struggling Oregon secondary.
Tony Brooks-James and Taj Griffin could see time at receiver for Oregon to make up for Marshall's absence.
Former UO cornerback Ifo Ekpre-Olomu is expected to collect $3 million in a loss of draft value insurance payment.
Helfrich likes the way the Ducks have responded to the Utah shellacking.
Brad Rock of the Deseret News: Oregon owns the uniform gimmick, but nothing says flashy like 62-20.
Pac-12 analyst Nigel Burton says Oregon's uncertainty at the QB position could make the future "scary."
The Ducks say they won't make the call on a starting quarterback until game time.
Jason Vondersmith of the Portland Tribune wonders how much confidence the UO coaches have in either quarterback.
UO linebacker Tyson Coleman is the guest on The O's latest UO podcast.
The O's Andrew Greif looks at the Oregon-Colorado matchups and projects a double-digit UO victory.
UO special teams coach Tom Osborne credits Utah for surprising the Ducks, and accentuates the positives.
Five things to watch in the Oregon-Colorado game.
Colorado defensive back Jered Bell has seen everything in a tenure that includes four head coaches.
Colorado's backup quarterbacks prepare in case they're needed against the Ducks.
Colorado running back Phillip Lindsay's toughness and attitude stand out.
Seth Collins' maturation at quarterback shows in Oregon State's passing game.
Oregon State football: Seth Collins, Beavers passing game steadily improving Just how far have Beavers true freshman quarterback Seth Collins and the Oregon State passing game come in four games?
Gina Mizell and Danny Moran of The O weigh in on OSU's first four games in their latest podcast.
Portland State's unbeaten Vikings will ride their defense into a Big Sky showdown with North Dakota.
North Dakota linebacker Will Ratelle is a problem the Vikings will need to solve.
Blake Martinez is a one-man , destruction machine for the Stanford defense.
Martinez is from Tucson, but Arizona didn't recruit him. Former Arrizona coach Mike Stoops thought he wasn't good enough.
Arizona receiver Johnny Jackson is eager for another crack at Stanford.
Arizona and Stanford to play for the first time in three years.
UCLA quarterback Josh Rosen is unafraid of the Arizona State blitz.
ASU receiver Devin Lucien is a grad transfer from UCLA, but the Bruins aren't worried about it.
UCLA receiver Jordan Payton has a body for football and a head for business.
Randall Goforth returns to cornerback for the Bruins.
Injuries force changes to the UCLA defense's goal-line package.
UCLA kicker Ka'imi Fairbairn has become a quiet weapon with his booming kickoffs.
Freshman defensive end JoJo Wicker has been a bright sport for Arizona State's defense.
injured ASU corner Lloyd Carrington is expected to play against UCLA.
Despite a good performance last week by USC's defense, defensive coordinator Justin Wilcox remains under fire.
USC receiver Steven Mitchell has been a big-play guy, and he says there is more to come.
Freshman linebacker Cameron Smith emerges as a playmaker for USC.
Washington State running back Keith Harrington's biggest fan always has been his dad.
WSU kicker Erik Powell has made himself mentally stronger.
Nickelback is the right fit for Cal's Cameron Walker.
Cal running back Daniel Lasco is expected to play against Wazzu.
Lasco has practiced all week as the Bears look healthier.
Cal safety Griffin Piatt returns from injury, and just in time.
Gordon Monson of the Salt Lake Tribune: This Utah team has a chance to be great.
UW offensive coordinator Jonathan Smith says his unit has plenty to work on.
Tucson's new bowl game will be known as the Arizona Bowl.
The links from Duck Sports Now.
The links from Beaver Sports Now.
